nodes.label: PALP_3659
nodes.l_description:
IX.1.20 Pompeii. W.344. Room 9, drawing of east wall of triclinium. 
In the panel on the left, at the north end of the east wall would have been the Muse Urania.
In the central panel would have been a painting of Venus and the evening star (or Aphrodite and Hesperus)
See Helbig, W., 1868. Wandgemälde der vom Vesuv verschƒütteten Städte Campaniens. Leipzig: Breitkopf und Härtel. (367)
In the panel on the right, at the south end of the east wall would have been the Muse Terpsichore.
See Gallo, A. (2000): I quadri perduti del triclinio ‚“S‚” della casa di M. Epidio Rufo. (p.89) in Assoc. Internazionale Amici di Pompei: Rivista di Studi Pompeiani, XI, 2000, ‚“L‚'Erma‚” di Bretschneider, Rome, (p.87-100)
Photo by Tatiana Warscher. Photo ‚é Deutsches Archäologisches Institut, Abteilung Rom, Arkiv.

nodes.label: PPM11_957
nodes.l_description:
208. IX 1, 22 House of M. Epi-dius Sabinus.
Pencil on paper; 450 x 315.
Under the frame on the left of Pompei Nicola Painting the Fox 1866; Right: Ima House following that of Suedio Clemente; right, confusing between the dashed lines in correspondence with the gap of Pompei Painting Nicola La Volpe 1866.
Archaeological Superintendency of Naples ADS 968.
Another genre scene, but to be considered almost as an "everyday �vita", was depicted in the framework of the same cubicle wall S (z), already very spoiled at the time of excavation, but documented before the total disappearance, as well as from this drawing, even a picture of 1943 (cfr. PPP III, p. 405). The representation is defined Toilet of Venus: you see a girl who is approaching with a cassette to a woman sitting next to which are two other attendants that will help in the preparation. It may indeed be a real scene and not necessarily related only to the world of the gods.

nodes.label: PALP_52352
nodes.l_description:
IX.1.22 Pompeii. Room 7, tablinum. 1886 painting of wall decoration, but with central painting of cupids in a boat.
See DAmelio P., 1886. Dipinti Murali di Pompei. Naples: Richter. Pl. XVII.
Schefold said that this was how the severely destroyed west wall would have looked, except that the Hermaphrodite and Silenus painting would have been seen in the centre, and not the cupids.
See Schefold, K., 1957. Die Wände Pompejis. Berlin: De Gruyter. (p.237)
See also photo by Tatiana Warscher. W.347. http://arachne.uni-koeln.de/item/marbilderbestand/230934

nodes.l_description:
10. Cubicle (b), wall N: the frieze above the median zone to bore depictions oligocromo among which, in correspondence with the framework with Actaeon, was the scene of the death of Pelias reproduced in Table. XIX Atlas of Helbig. The center of the composition is made up of the great cauldron placed over the fire in an ornate pillar in bandages towards which advances the old Pelias accompanied by a daughter and followed by another carrying the still-born inguai sword, but relieved; from right comes another Peliade with the ram and finally Medea with his head covered and in the right magic herbs.
by Helbig, Alias, Tav. XIX, at the bottom (Fot. Rossini)

Looking towards south wall of tablinum, ‚“X‚” marks the location where the painting was removed from. 
According to Warscher – 
The painting of the Three Graces was located on the central panel of the south wall of the tablinum.
There was no other central painting on the north wall: there was a large opening into the adjacent house no.17.
(La pittura delle Tre Grazie trovavasi sul pannello centrale della parete sud del tablino.
Non vi era un‚'altra pittura centrale sulla parete nord: vi era una grande apertura nella casa adiacente No.17.)
See Warscher, T. 1942. Catalogo illustrato degli affreschi del Museo Nazionale di Napoli. Sala LXXXII. Vol.4. Rome, Swedish Institute.

nodes.l_description: 34. Environment (1), S. Low white wall socket; median zone: narrow central compartment with vegetable candelabrum, side panels with medallions and carpet edges to a single line delimited by a red band; white upper zone: tight compartment delimited by red bands with garland; side panels with garland stretched between two carpet edges in two parallel lines; white bezel with birds and cherries, holes for the beams; IV style. the remains of a stucco frame with pointed bezel plastered (II style are also visible?). The de Vos has attributed the decoration of this environment to the workshop of Via di Castricio Painters, in particular for the garland taut and the branches to S, and for the type of candlestick tortile in the narrow compartment that separates the two panels (De Vos, proma , p. 125). 77 N34774

nodes.label: PPM2_28
nodes.l_description: 28. Cubicle (8), N wall, central section, upper zone. The painting depicts Apis, the sacred bull of Memphis, proceeding to the W (towards the entrance door to the room). The magpie perched on the frame indicates that the bull is intended as the soul (ba) of Osiris. In Memphis the funeral of Apis took place according to the rites of the cult of Osiris: the intestines were kept in four canopic jars, which we see above the epistyle of the pergola: two exposed next to the painting, the other two next to the painting on the wall S.

nodes.label: PPM2_43
nodes.l_description: 43. Cubicle (8), S wall, central section, upper zone. A heron and a magpie perched in correspondence with the two swings hanging on the sides of the painting depicting the Apis bull. It proceeds to the E, as does the Satyr who comes running into the relief below: that is, towards the back wall, where Dionysus is represented. The two poded amphorae with lid placed on the epistyle complete the other two painted on the N wall: probably these are the four containers of the mummy's intestine, the so-called canopes.

nodes.label: PPM2_44
nodes.l_description: 44. Cubicle (8), S wall, central section and W, upper zone. The jay perched on the painting depicting Apis seems to be in conversation with the magpie. A retrospicient blackbird sits on the handle of the canopus of Apis' mummy.

nodes.label: PPM2_399
nodes.l_description: 16. Triclinium (11), N wall with a hole, made by ancient prospectors, which are matched by those existing on E and S walls. The plinth is made of imitation marble panels. The central area, red, has a large panel in the center with a figure in flight, softened by birds and garlands, which also decorate the top of the side panels. The usual fillers alternate in the upper white area. Also in this environment, as in the tablinum (5), we note the attempt to create a more ambitious decoration. The decorative scheme and some details are comparable with those of the oecus (g) of the Fullonica by Stephanus, I 6, 7. IV style.

The Lararium painting has two large diagonal snakes, one either side of a painted round altar. Above the snakes is a garland. In the background are bushes with green leaves and red flowers. Over each bush is a fluttering bird. In front of the painted altar is a four sided real altar which was painted with red, blue and yellow spots. See Fröhlich, T., 1991, Lararien und Fassadenbilder in den Vesuvstädten. Mainz: von Zabern. (L20: p.258 and tafel 3,2).

nodes.l_description: 13. Tablino (11), wall And with recessed for the bed: black socket panels with plants separated by compartments. In the white median zone are found many of the typical elements of the repertoire of Bottega of Via di Castricio Painters: the cartoons with peacocks, the panels with carpet edges in two parallel lines, the candlestick golden tortile (N) and the plant (in S) in tight compartments that separate them; a yellow frame with lod separates the median from the white area above with stylized kiosks from which hang a tambourine in the center and a rhytón N (S disappeared), taut garlands and carpet edges to square. IV style.

nodes.label: PPM3_5
nodes.l_description: 4. Kitchen (3), wall S, section E above the masonry counter. The opus incertum walls of the kitchen were covered with rough plaster, with a special layer of smooth white plaster applied on top for the painting of the Lares. These appear, as usual, in a symmetrical group with the outer hand raised to pour the wine from the rhytón into the situla held in the other hand, lowered. The altar and the offerer depicted among the Lares are surmounted by a double-sided tabula with the dedication Felix Larìbus / con [se] c [rat] volum (CIL IV 9887). Above the scene a polychrome garland hangs with the ends hanging down on the sides. Next to the Lare on the right is a pig's head; under the laying surface of the Lares you can see the remains of the snake, and a ham (?). AFS A1577 (formerly A8740)sata with the dedication Felix Larìbus / with [se] {c m] vaimi (CIL IV 9887). Above the scene a garland Po-ROYAL IIlicroma is hung with the ends falling on the sides. Next to Lare right figure a pig's head; under the subfloor of the Lares are the remains of the snake, and a ham (?).AFS A1577 (A8740 already)

nodes.label: PPM3_496
nodes.l_description: 61. Cubicle (11), wall N. section to the W of the door. Above the plinth, the black plinth is divided into a square placed in the corner W, with a patera suspended in the center and an acroterion in the shape of a volute and semi-flat, from which a garland attached to the narrow candlestick compartment starts. A head of iris blooms in the panel next to the door. The median area has a central aedicule, regardless of the interruption of the door; the base, seen in perspective, remains of the two columns supporting the roof of the aedicule, with the purple predella. Much of the blue side panel with cinnabar red border has collapsed. In the relatively modest environment, the wall decoration is embellished not only by the use of a small module for ornaments, but also by the presence of two expensive and difficult to apply colors: the Egyptian frit and the cinnabar. 77 N39486

The lead strip at the base of the wall was inserted by modern restorers to stop the capillary action of the underground humidity in the wall. The window in wall W of the cubicle overlooks the garden. 77 N39492

nodes.label: PPM3_492
nodes.l_description: 57. Oecus (10), wall S. The red-brown base decorated with garlands and carpet edges is interrupted by narrow compartments, of which the left one remains with a swan flying towards the corner of the room. The central area preserves the architecture that fills the entire wall starting from the frame of the plinth; from the central aedicule with a yellow background the painting is removed, probably by the Bourbons who disturbed the nearby chapel and will also be responsible for the breaking through of wall E. In front of the side wings there are carpets yellow with overpainted medallions (the one on the left peeled off, the other removed): two peacocks are poised on the upper edge of the tapped, supported by a twisted candelabrum on the side of the architectural views flanking the central aedicule. Closed by a green pluteus, the glimpses with a white background open onto a portico with garlands hanging from a clypeus fixed on the epistyle and acroteria in the shape of a sea monster. Of the upper floor, which is also porticoed, only the lower part of a few columns remains. 77 N39499

The cocciopesto channel that was to collect rainwater at the foot of wall N was filled illusionistically by the four painted fountains.

nodes.label: PPM3_843
nodes.l_description: 50. Triclinium (p), wall E. The function of the environment is ensured by the recess for the triclinium bed, an element that became typical of cubicles and tricliniums during the imperial age. The decoration follows the same patterns and motifs as that of the tablinum (n) and the triclinium (d) and shows with great clarity the stylistic and syntactic characteristics of the transition phase between the III and IV styles. In fact, the black plinth with a very simple geometric partition can be fully inserted in the most ancient phase, while the flat aedicule that occupies the center of the wall, the motif of the garland stretched to frame the panels, now transformed into that of the carpet edge, the rich chromatic play based on the clear alternation of red, yellow, white and black and accentuated by the sharp contrast between the overall dark tones of the central area and the white of the upper area, the motifs that frame the friezes with birds, are all elements that now herald the IV style. III style, phase IIB. 77 N44410

nodes.label: PPM3_837
nodes.l_description: 44. Tablino (n), S side. The large opening that connects the atrium and the tablinum also houses a decoration, consisting of a pilaster painted with a black background bordered by red bands and adorned with garlands of ivy leaves. The motif of the painted pilaster is similar to the one on the wing (m) and is particularly popular in this period. III style, phase IIB. 77 N44401

The old photograph, done at the time of the excavation, compared with that of the opposite wall (fig. 6), it reproduces a situation much less degraded than the current one and allows you to read more clarity the stylistic features of the decoration, already clearly "straddling 'between ÌIJ and IV style. In the center of the wall, above the geometric base, is a light aedicule in front of the series of panels divided by strips with V-shaped motifs; in the panels, birds in flight and rampant animals; in the upper area continues the central aedicule, flanked by light architecture. Style III, phase II B. AFS C960

nodes.label: PPM3_972
nodes.l_description: 32. Cubicle (a), N wall: the median area during the restoration, before the integration of the missing plaster. For the scenographic architecture the colors used are: green for the podium (a color since the Republican era used for this element), the forepart of the temple, the lateral partitions in opus quadratum, the pillars O and E bearing the epistyle with acroterial winged sphinx, also green; yellow for the doors of the pronaos, the lateral podiums of the temple and podiums and windows on the sides; the architectures in the background and the background itself are monochromatic in red. The balconies supported by shelves above the side partitions in opus quadratimi are white. Iphigenia, the head covered by a veil and with the mantic net and two branches in the lowered right, the xòanon ​​(composed of the three bodies and six torches) of Hekate in the left, followed by two priestesses with a crown of flowers on their hair and a plate with flowers on his right, he is about to descend the steps to lustrate the idol of Artemis with the bronze hydria, which is already ready on display on the first step. Leaning on the right podium we see the two swords taken from Orestes and Pylades taken prisoner, on the right, naked except for the chlamys, with their hands tied behind their backs. Orestes, who has not yet been recognized by his sister Iphigenia, is depicted frontally, Pylades from behind and from three quarters. Toante king of Thrace, he is seated on the left: with a beard, he has a barbarian appearance, he wears a short chiton like the guard with clypeus behind him, who wears the miter that covers his chin, anassirides and the long cloak also brought by the Trojan soldiers of Laomedon to the nearby house II 2, 2 (h). The archaizing cult statue of Artemis, wearing a short chiton (the idol has symmetrically open arms like Lenino's Chryse, which belongs to the Agamemnon cycle and is identified with Artemis Tauria) and has two crossed arrows in the left, you can see behind Iphigenia. The idol of the goddess appears in the center of a thòlos, whose epistyle supported by Ionic capitals, rises above the triangular tympanum of the pronaos and whose conical roof with spire stands out between the edge of the plaster and the coffered ceiling with an adorned frame. antefix in the shape of a palmette. The rampant centaurs in function of acroterion, carry a torch in the hand facing the center of the wall and a plate in the other. The stucco frame is decorated with hanging lotuses alternating with buds. AFS C1213

nodes.label: PPM3_909
nodes.l_description: 16. Triclinium (6), corner NW. The environment has an elegant - albeit banal - style IV decoration, which accentuates the center of the walls, diversifying the decoration with respect to the side panels. The red plinth alternates panels with plants with narrow compartments with floral corollas. In the middle area, with a black background, the central panels are embellished with garlands wrapped around thin candelabra, which branch off from another low candelabra at the base of the panel; narrow compartments crossed by candelabra or stretched garlands divide the central panels from the side panels, in which birds or rampant animals stand out. The upper area is also black, articulated by flat aedicules. The still life with fish in the center of wall N refers to the function of the environment, while the black background of the environment makes it possible to recognize a winter triclinium. IV style. AFSC1142

nodes.l_description: 7. Room (4), wall E. The decoration, with a black monochrome background, is based on a bipartite scheme: in the center is an architectural foreshortening closed by a partition decorated with a Gorgon's head; in the side panels, delimited by carpet edges, two large female figures in flight stand out. Also in the plinth, with rich bushes of plants, the division of the central area is proposed again, according to a pattern of distribution of the decoration that is normally reserved for smaller rooms. IV style. The painting is done on a closed door that led to the courtyard (15). Spinazzola, fig. 711

nodes.l_description: 14. Triclinio (b), S view wall during the excavation. The landscape with architecture on the red background of the central panel flanked by black pilasters with columns provided with horns and hanging cymbals. The vignettes in the center of the yellow and red side panels depict rampant deer and griffins; The panels are separated by black pilasters with grotesque candelabrum composed of pairs of dolphins and craters, which also divide the black friezes above (pecking birds). The central aedicule with a yellow background in the white upper area houses a painting depicting a portico on top of two | Stairs. The garlands of palmettes in the portico of the upper area connect the central aedicule with the side ones with a red background with a mystical cist hanging. A molded stucco frame closes this area of the wall.25 AFS CI458

nodes.label: PPM1_788
nodes.l_description: 91. Environment (g), N- angle E. White Lintonaco of the middle zone, compromise the holes for the shelving, painted with a cartoon depicting a amorino in flight holding a situici Siaca in breast-shaped, enclosing the sacred milk, in right hand and a torch in his left hand, and with a cupid cartoon holding with both hands the rosy crown, a crown woven of rose petals. In the upper zone I am hung a tambourine and a drinking horn, and flying a swan and two phoenixes. Dolphins acroterial flank a gorgoneon. The horizontal meander over the window and the contours of the cupids are graffiti before being painted. They are to be noted the cut at the bottom of the upper zone margin, charged at the time of applying the ointment of the middle zone, and lincisivit kyma of white stucco lesbio that mask the joint between the wall and ceiling. I5AFS C852

nodes.l_description:
53a-e. Triclinio (s), wall O. The wall consists of the doorway toward the corridor (k), for which the local newsagent side in a red background with missing branch of the lower tract. The painting depicts Dionysus

to a white central nelledicola bottom contrasts with the black bottom of the socket and the side panels: the white background of the framework and the upper area with the Thlos god expresses the light emanating from these

nellepifania (nocte media saw solem: Apul., Mei., 11,285. 23). The acroteria of Thlos and side newsagents depict parrots with Egyptian crowns, refer to Osiris that has life and very similar to those miracles

Dionysus. The cup-shaped craters are decorated with flowers mo
the thyrsus.

Drawing D. Michel, p. 649, Fig- 14; DAIB 80.3742; 80.3751: 80.3744

A A 1986 80.3741;



x54. Triclinio (s), O wall, and upper median zone. From straight garlands hang from parrots mystical cyst, with half-open lid. II thyrsos constituted by a cane or other plant stem crowned by a dedera bunch or a pine cone, the scepter of Dionysus. The garlands that parrots hold in its beak are presumably melilot, such as those that Osiris Nephtys to leave, according to Plutarch (Mor356F, 366B); The cyst will contain sacred or mysleria. 15AFS C844

nodes.label: PPM1_269
nodes.l_description:
76. Peristyle (56), Wall N, section E of the door. Reproduction graphics from the manual Mau, documenting the decorative wall system: geometric socket crosses: median zone in yellow and red panels adorned by a medallion with swan, a framework with liortus ended ^, a segment of a circle or a landscape picture, and separated by narrow blacks compartments with candlestick, column or pillar. The entire decoration of the panels matching the theme of nature and the garden. The upper zone ornate. The paratactical scheme is particularly suited to environments of passage.
E 104524 (from Mau W, pi. XI)

nodes.label: PALP_43168
nodes.l_description:
I.6.12 Pompeii. October 2013. Painted decoration on south wall.
Photo courtesy of Paula Lock. 
In this room, the low zoccolo/plinth was yellow and sprinkled with red.
Above the zoccolo, in the middle zone of the south wall are the remains of two large red painted panels, with a narrow yellow panel between them.
Hanging in the red panels were painted garlands, shields, discs and lances; the vignette in the centre of the east panel depicted a dove, and the vignette in the centre of the other red panel showed a couple of doves on a branch.
In the yellow panel was a painted figure.
According to de Vos in PPM, the male figure dressed in a green tunic and red cloak, painted on a yellow background, held a decoy bird in his raised right hand and a long twig (una paniuzza) in his left hand, and was standing on a cage that served for transport and base for the decoy. 
The upper zone of the wall was painted white and divided into panels by red vertical borders.
See Carratelli, G. P., 1990-2003. Pompei: Pitture e Mosaici: Vol. 1, Roma: Istituto della enciclopedia italiana, p. 398-9.

2. Bottega (m), S wall, stretch to E of the retro- shop door (n). Above a low yellow socket sprayed red, the central zone has two large red panels separated by a narrow yellow panel. In red panels are hung with garlands, shields, medallions and rods; cartoon at the center of the panel E depicts a dove, and the sticker in the center dellaltro red panel a pair of cutlery addressed doves on a branch. The yellow panel painted as if it were a carpet lined with a textile pattern of triangles, and inflated by the wind as suggested by the garlands strained arched along the sides. At the center appears a male figure in a green tunic with red cloak knotted over his chest and hanging over her shoulder. The white upper area divided into compartments by red vertical edges.
77 N35263

In the centre is the painting of Ariadne seated on the ground watching the ship of Theseus sailing away. 
Nemesis is at her shoulders and Cupid is turned towards her, holding his bow and wiping away his tears.
See D‚'Amelio P., 1886. Dipinti Murali di Pompei. Naples: Richter. Pl. V.
According to PPM this is not completely faithful in some particulars.
See Pompei: Pitture e Mosaici, Vol. VIII, Roma: Istituto della enciclopedia italiana, p. 1055.

nodes.label: PALP_9262
nodes.l_description:
V.2.h Pompeii. December 2005. Room 'L‚', east wall with decoration on a yellow background. The triclinium had a floor of signinum, and the walls were decorated with panelled yellow backgrounds separated by narrow compartments with garlands. The zoccolo/dado was of red/purple with painted plants. It received light from two windows, one in the west wall overlooking the garden, and the other in the south wall looking into room 'm‚'. In the west wall, near to the entrance doorway, was a rectangular niche (height 0.78m width 0.49m). This would have been faced internally with wood on the sides, and at the back it was plastered with the same yellow as the walls. At the foot of the east wall were two large blocks of limestone, remains of ancient construction.
See Notizie degli Scavi, 1896, (p.423) where the triclinium is room 'g‚'.
See Mau in BdI, VIII, 1893, (p.14-27)

nodes.label: PALP_5408
nodes.l_description:
V.2.d Pompeii. May 2005. Looking towards the north-east corner of the triclinium.
The blocked window in north wall overlooked V.2.i, and was blocked after excavation. The holes for the support beams of an upper room can be seen in the walls. This upper room would have been reached by the masonry steps against the east wall in the previous photos. In the remains of the yellow panel of the north wall, just visible in the centre would have been a painting of monochrome green glass vases on a yellow background. According to PPM, the middle zone of the north wall was decorated with yellow side panels, and a red panel in the centre edged with ‚“carpet‚” border and separated by black compartments with painted cane/reeds. In the red panel, the remains of a central painting were found but only the upper half remained. On the white upper zone would have been architecture and painted garlands together with a stucco cornice. Not a lot remains of the decoration of the east wall.

nodes.label: PALP_2931
nodes.l_description:
V.2.d Pompeii, but shown as V.2.15 on the photo. 1937-39. Looking towards vaulted niche lararium on upper north wall, in north-east corner of rear of house. Photo courtesy of American Academy in Rome, Photographic Archive. Warsher collection no. 596
According to Boyce, there were two lararia in the house. One on the north wall of a rear room that occupied the place of the peristyle, high above the floor, was a large arched niche (0.8m high, 0.65m wide, 0.35m deep, 2.9m high above the floor) with a heavy projecting ledge beneath it. Painted on the back wall of this niche, was a burning altar adorned with a garland and furnished with two eggs, and on each side of the altar was a palm branch, yellow with red ribbon attached. The wall around the niche was covered with white stucco which below the niche was studded with red spots representing a dado, down as far as a row of holes, where a kind of mezzanine was attached, by means of which the niche was reached. At a late date this structure was removed and Mau supposed that the niche was reached thereafter by a portable ladder.
See Boyce G. K., 1937. Corpus of the Lararia of Pompeii. Rome: MAAR 14. (p.36, nos.101 and 102,)
BdI 1885, p.256.
According to PPM, nothing remains of the painting other than a small amount of the base stucco.

nodes.label: PALP_47244
nodes.l_description:
V.2.c Pompeii. 1931. Room ‚“b‚”. Lararium painting.
DAIR 31.1772. Photo ‚é Deutsches Archäologisches Institut, Abteilung Rom, Arkiv. 
According to Boyce, this was a finely preserved lararium painting including a broad red stripe on all sides.
In the upper part, the Genius, wreathed and holding cornucopia in his left, poured a libation from a patera held in his right.
The cylindrical altar, painted in red and yellow imitation marble, had a blazing fire on its top. 
On the opposite side of the altar, a tibicen in long white robe played the double flutes.
On each side, stood a Lar wearing tunic and pallium and holding a rhyton and situla.
The tunic of each Lar had a broad red stripe down the front and was yellow and blue.
The pallium was red. Three garlands were painted across the top, and two others hung down at the side.
Above the garland were three divinities – the Sun, Mercury and another, possibly the Moon, but even then disappeared.
Underneath, a yellow and brown serpent with red crest creeps towards an altar with fire and an egg on top.
On the right side of this altar is the figure of Sarnus, lying in the middle of aquatic plants. 
He is very small compared to the serpent.
On the left side of the serpent, corresponding to Sarnus on the right, was another figure but also had disappeared by then.
The background of both zones was filled with plants with red flowers. Above the serpent, was a single flying bird.
See Boyce G. K., 1937. Corpus of the Lararia of Pompeii. Rome: MAAR 14. (p.36, no.99, Pl. 17,1)

The house, excavated between 1883 and 1884 is of modest proportions and has an internal distribution of rather irregular environments, dating, however, already in the early phases of construction of the building, since in some environments, the remains were recognized of a decor of 1 style [bezel (k) and at the (e) and inputs (ics)], which are also to exclude the presence of alae atrium sides. The entrance was through the fauces (a) used, probably, given the proportions and the presence of an arched niche on the wall N, E of the door, even as a workshop. In the floor of this was the receipt for the repa-giiluvr, even the lobby floor is to lavapesta (currently threatened compline-mind in light, is still in good condition) with regular and irregular flakes plates marble, among which prevail hexes, scattered. It establishes the dating between the end of the second and the first half of 1 sec. B.C., he presented in the tub a pillar sorreggente a statuette of Venus to the bathroom, preceded by a rectangular marble pan, which remain the supports; on the edge, in the N-O it was a white marble fluted monopodio, supporting a round table; S-E of the same, embedded in the floor, a terracotta puteal, mouthpiece, evidently, the cistern below. While almost nothing remains of the decoration of the walls of the atrium, performed before 62 AD, but already in the IV style, is still clearly visible in the niche lararium to input E in which, above the head of Zeus enthroned , there was a nail, probably sospendervi a garland. Around alfatrio, therefore, they are arranged without any symmetry [with the exception of that between the scale for the upper floor to O (d ') and the pantry (m)

E, obtained in all likelihood by the elimination of the scale at the time of construction of the other scale (q), located in the SE of the peristyle], the cubicle (d), the environment (s) adapted in recent times, despite its large size to deposit, the triclinium (n), the cubicles (1), (k) used as a pantry, and (i), of reduced dimensions so as to suggest the anomalous presence of a slavish room. The tablinum (g), which also communicated with (e), was open towards the peristyle (p), via a high step, covered with a threshold of gray marble which preserves the footprints (rust stains) of a closure to six flying .
The flanks towards the environment E (h), can also be reached from the atrium, characterized by the presence of a wall parallel to the wall E, which serves as a support to a group of jars, in there deposited. For O is the cubicle (f) that has an eye-catching on the wall plaster restoration O. The peristyle has three arms, each of which features different-mind from the others: the southern one, which was also the highest, presented by E a door wall, which abuts on the scale (q), a mainstay in the Sarno limestone blocks, an angular column in support of the overlying solarium; Or what of four columns (including the already mentioned angular) and a pillar at an angle at the northern end; the porch N shows, finally, two columns incorporated to a fourth pillars, as well as angular, are coated with rough plaster, on the contrary of the columns painted in yellow, which proves a consolidation intervention of the load-bearing structures the overlying solarium, which at the time of the excavation still it retained remnants of the parapet and decoration of the bottom wall, in yellow with plants.
The materials used in the construction of the portico S (Sarno limestone and tuff) and the fact that the raceway of collection of the falling water from solariun continues below that of the porch O and partecipates � the presence of a clay eaves with leonine heads and pal -mette in the back wall of the viridarium placed at the same height of the door wall that holds the sun, shows that at first there was only a garden with south porch. In AD 79 however, it was not over the arrangement of the walls, if we consider that the same remains only the upper part of the area and for the rest there is only rintonaco raw. On the bottom of the building are the triclinium (r) which leads to the small pantry (s), the cubicle
(U) behind which is the kitchen (v), reachable through the corridor (t) and in which, in addition to the hearth and the latrine was a scale that allowed to ascend to a bedroom placed on (s) and to the solarium .
In this area we can see several remakes: dall'addossamento the eastern wall (r) to the existing wall, the closure of
an existing port in the southern part of the same wall (r), and subsequently to the decoration of the latter, taken in the same style, but with a different hand and going to insert a bipartite scheme in a context symmetric structure (cfr. Figs. 40 -42). Interesting is the choice of soggètti depicted in the paintings of the triclinium, three banquet scenes realistically rendered with great detail, some of which have acquired peculiar interest as a result of discoveries made in the 70s of this century. This refers to the statue of bronze efebo supporting a canteen, which appears as part of the west wall, which has found its "�originale" in bronze discovered in 1977 in the House of Julius Polybius, who, unlike other similar statues , already known, that supported lamps, maintained with open palms a rectangular canteen found together. It is speculated that the scenes represent different moments of the feast, but not of the same feast, as the ambientazio-ne and the characters are different; or that are banquet scenes at different times of year Jackets � cartoons in the side panels appear the personifications of the Seasons, but the link between the clothing of the banqueting and the season corresponding to it should be tried by a small stretch, on the opposite wall . In the home, however, another reference to the wine was in a medallion of Bacchus head crowned with ivy and thyrsus on the shoulder, which was located on the wall of the atrium O and who could not find in any other pendant medallion. The presence of numerous graffiti in the columns of the peristyle, executed by Fullone L. Quintilius Crescens, which manifests itself in more ways his exaltation, greeting the caupo (CIL IV 4100), then the fullones, the sacred owl to Minerva (CIL IV 4118) , Pompey, the Salinienses, Stabiae and the Surrentini (CIL IV 4102, 4103, 4109), up to the state to be there reborn (CIL IV 4107), has led to the hypothesis Della Corte at this house had been intended, at least in 'last period of life of the city in caupona', is more likely instead of Sogliano the hypothesis about the existence of relations between the owner, or the inhabitant of this house, and the nearest workshop fullones VI 14,22. Different tone had decoration III final style of the small cubicle (u) that appeared on the S wall, opened with a window on the peristyle, a sacral landscape and on the other pictures on the walls of a uniform subject being represented in them pairs of teacher and pupil, identified with diotime and Socrates, Corinna and Pindar. Sappho and a girl.

63a-b-c. Exedra (y), wall E. The central picture depicts a wide and tall pink circular base in a wooded, with golden statue of Dionysus (Moormann: Arianna) sitting in a relaxed pose, his left arm resting on the tambourine, the right raised above the head holding a Kantha ros. He's watched from the back-spiciente panther, which jumps to the side. The landscape is illuminated by the right as if the light came from the door in the S. wall (The graphic rendering is from Mau). The architecture depicted on illusionistic exedra side walls seem to be made of a wooden frame painted with figurative painting inserted in the center of the wall, flanked by niches with cinnabar red background on the basis statues (cf.. Vitruvius, signorum megalographiam will deorum simulacra: De Arch., 7.5.1). The center console is repaired by a shrine with columns in squa-

nodes.label: PALP_63442
nodes.l_description: VI.10.11 Pompeii. Room 3, looking towards south-west corner of atrium. See Gell, W, 1832. Pompeiana: Vol 1. London: Jennings and Chaplin. p. 180, plate 62. The paintings in the panels on the walls do not seem to be completely accurate, it may have been painted from memory to give an impression of the atrium. Gell?s description reads? ?The walls when first discovered, were covered with brilliant colours, and much more might have been traced with regard to the details of the ornaments than is here represented, but the fact is, that by a variety of petty intrigues, strangers are prevented from drawing these objects, till they are either defaced or irrecoverably destroyed, and it is only by the despatch supplied by the camera lucida, that any memorial of them can be obtained. These walls of the atrium being higher than the rest are already in a tottering state, and possibly this plate may soon be the only record of their existence?. Photo courtesy of Rick Bauer.
